content: The "Third Higher Education Extension Act of 2007" extends programs until March 31, 2008. It clarifies that previous acts do not limit appropriations or program durations. Amendments are made to the definition of eligible not-for-profit holders. Section 435(p) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include provisions regarding trustees acting on behalf of various entities regardless of their eligibility as lenders. The amendment to Section 435(p) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 allows trustees to act on behalf of certain entities, regardless of their eligibility as lenders, if they were the sole beneficial owner of a loan eligible for special allowance payment under section 438 at the time of the College Cost Reduction and Access Act enactment. The amendment to Section 435(p) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 allows trustees to act on behalf of certain entities, regardless of their eligibility as lenders, if they were the sole beneficial owner of a loan eligible for special allowance payment under section 438 at the time of the College Cost Reduction and Access Act enactment. In subparagraph (A)(ii), "waive the requirements" is amended by inserting "of" after. Subparagraph (B) states that no for-profit entity can own or control a not-for-profit holder under this Act. The amendment to Section 435(p) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 allows trustees to act on behalf of certain entities, regardless of their eligibility as lenders, if they were the sole beneficial owner of a loan eligible for special allowance payment under section 438 at the time of the College Cost Reduction and Access Act enactment. No State, political subdivision, authority, agency, instrumentality, trustee, or other entity described in paragraph (1)(A), (B), (C), or (D) shall be an eligible not-for-profit holder under this Act with respect to any loan, or income from any loan, unless owned or controlled by a for-profit entity. The Act specifies that certain entities must be the sole beneficial owner of a loan and its income, or have a trustee hold the loan on their behalf, to be eligible under the Higher Education Act. The Act requires specific entities to be the sole beneficial owner of a loan and its income to be eligible under the Higher Education Act. Amendments include expanding the definition of eligible entities to include various state and local organizations. The Act specifies that certain entities must be the sole owner of a loan and its income to qualify under the Higher Education Act. This includes state and local organizations being eligible lenders, regardless of ownership by for-profit entities or pledging collateral for debt obligations.
